newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian police detain arms-laden ship in Bombay.
newsitem.headline: Indian police detain arms-laden ship in Bombay.

text.p: A ship carrying ammunition and small arms, including grenades and Russian-made AK-56 rifles, was detained at Bombay port on Thursday, police officials said on Saturday.
Police said the Burmese-flagged MV Pacdream was scheduled to stop at Madras before heading for Chittagong in Bangladesh.
Deputy police commissioner Madhu Shinde said the ship's Korean captain claimed it had been chartered by the United Nations but he had no documents to prove this.
A senior U.N. official in Delhi said he had no knowledge of the ship.
"I know nothing about this ship or its destination. I am caught completely by surprise," U.N. resident representative H.C. Graf von Sponeck told Reuters.
The Pacdream arrived in Bombay to discharge some general cargo on September 17.
A senior police official said the ship started its journey in Houston, Texas, and had called at Mobile, Haiti, Durban, Mombasa and Karachi before reaching Bombay.
"The ship was detained because it did not have relevant documents or the Indian government's permission to carry arms and ammunition," said Shinde.
The ship's 23-man crew -- four Koreans, including its captain, and 19 Burmese nationals -- were also detained, police said.
